'''UNESCO Nomenclature''' (more properly '''UNESCO nomenclature for fields of science and technology''') is a system developed by [[UNESCO]] for [[Categorization|classification]] of research papers and [[doctoral dissertation]]s. There are three versions of the system, offering different levels of refinement through [[UNESCO Nomenclature|2]]-, [[4-digit UNESCO Nomenclature|4]]-, and 6-digit codes. ==Six-digit system== The following links do not link directly to topics. Instead, they link to pages on which the 6-digit UNESCO nomenclature is described in more detail: it is far too large a system to cover on a single page. 11 [[6-digit UNESCO Nomenclature starting with 11|Logic]]

revision.text:
{{Mesopotamian myth|expanded=5}} In [[Mesopotamian religion|Akkadian and Sumerian mythology]], '''Alû''' is a [[vengeful spirit]] of the [[Utukku]] that goes down to the [[underworld]] [[Kur]]. The [[demon]] has no mouth, lips or ears. It roams at night and terrifies people while they sleep,{{cite book |title=Lilith-The First Eve: Historical and Psychological Aspects of the Dark Feminine |first=Siegmund |last=Hurwitz |year=1980 |url= https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=6T9Y1EhiwDUC&oi=fnd&pg=PA40#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=39 }} and [[Spirit possession|possession]] by Alû results in [[unconsciousness]] and [[coma]];[https://books.google.com/books?id=XC5kVw-ul4kC&pg=PA89&dq=Al%C3%BB+coma&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tgxPT5LSOoiItwevofHBDQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Al%C3%BB%20coma&f=false Disease in Babylonia By Irving L. Finkel, Markham J. Geller] in this manner it resembles creatures such as the [[Mare (folklore)|mara]], and [[incubus]], which are invoked to explain [[sleep paralysis]]. In Akkadian and Sumerian mythology, it is associated with other demons like [[Gallu]] and [[Lilu (mythology)|Lilu]]. ==In ancient texts== [[Stephen Herbert Langdon]] (1864) cites a translation of a [[cuneiform script]] by Major-General Sir [[H. C. Rawlinson]]. From v Pl. 50, A, line 42:
Whom in his bed the wicked Alû covered,
Whom the wicked ghost by night overwhelmed.
Langdon (364) stated that Alû is [[androgynous]] and "attacks a man's breast". The following passage quoted by Langdon shows the modus operandi of the Utukku:
The wicked Utukku who slays man alive on the plain.
The wicked Alû who covers (man) like a garment.
The wicked [[Etimmu]], the wicked [[Gallû]], who bind the body.
The [[Lamme]] ([[Lamashtu]]), the [[Lammea]] ([[Labasu]]), who cause disease in the body.
The [[Lilu (mythology)|Lilû]] who wanders in the plain.
They have come nigh unto a suffering man on the outside.
They have brought about a painful malady in his [[human body|body]].
The curse of [[evil]] has come into his body.
An evil [[goblin]] they have placed in his body.
An evil [[:wikt:bane|bane]] has come into his body.
Evil [[poison]] they have placed in his body.
An evil [[Curse|malediction]] has come into his parts.
Evil and trouble they have placed in his body.
Poison and taint have come into his body.
They have produced evil.
Evil [[being]], evil [[face]], evil [[mouth]], evil [[tongue]].
[[Magic (paranormal)|Sorcery]], [[venom]], slaver, wicked machinations,
Which are produced in the body of the [[Disease|sick]] man.
O woe for the sick man whom thy cause to moan like a šąharrat.
--(Langdon, 357, 362, 364) ==In contemporary popular culture== * Alû is [[Monster in My Pocket]] #113 * [[Alu-demon]] in [[Dungeons & Dragons]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Mythology|Ancient Near East}} *Langdon, Stephen Herbert. [[H. C. Rawlinson]] ''Cuneiform Inscriptions of Western Asia''. Vol. 4 (Semitic). ed. [[Theophilus Pinches]]. [[London]]: [[British Museum]], 1861–64, 1891. {{DEFAULTSORT:Alu}} [[Category:Mesopotamian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Sleep in mythology and folklore]]

{{affiliated sources|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox Museum |name = Atlanta History Center |image = |imagesize = 300 |caption = |map_type = Atlanta, Georgia |established = 1926 |location = 130 West Paces Ferry Road |type = History |president = Sheffield Hale |website = [http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/ Atlanta History Center] }} The '''Atlanta History Center (AHC)''' is a [[history museum]] and research center located in the [[Buckhead (Atlanta)|Buckhead]] district of [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. The Museum was founded in 1926, and currently consists of six permanent, and several temporary, exhibitions. The AHC campus is 33-acres and features historic gardens and houses located on the grounds, including [[Swan House (Atlanta, Georgia)|Swan House]], [[Tullie Smith House|Tullie Smith Farm]], and Wood Family Cabin. The AHC's research arm, the Kenan Research Center, includes 3.5 million resources and a reproduction of historian [[Franklin Garrett]]'s (1906–2000) office. The AHC holds one of the largest collections of [[American Civil War|Civil War]] artifacts in the United States.
==Exhibitions== The Atlanta History Center operates three types of exhibitions - permanent, temporary, and traveling. The six permanent exhibitions include:
* '''[[1996 Olympic Games|Centennial Olympic Games]] Museum''' is made up of two sections. One is the upper Sports Lab, accessible by elevator, in which one is able to test himself against the Olympic records. There is also the main area, in which there are artifacts from the Olympics, interactives, information, and films. One of the main attractions is the 12-part test, which allows one to test himself on his Olympic knowledge, and then posts a score. * '''Turning Point: The American Civil War''' exhibition contains 1,400 of the Atlanta History Center's enormous collection of Civil War artifacts. * '''Metropolitan Frontiers''' exhibit chronicles Atlanta's expansion from farm to city in four stages: Rural Region, Transportation Center, Commercial City, and Suburban Metropolis. Currently being updated under the working title, '''''Atlanta Stories''''' - set to open in April 2016. * '''Shaping Traditions: Folk Arts in a Changing South''' exhibit shows the development and attributes of Southern folk art. It includes forms ranging from clothing and food to singing and storytelling and presents both the traditional and the modern. * '''Down the Fairway with Bobby Jones''' exhibit is based on the life of Georgia's most famous golfer, [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]], and chronicles the early development of golf in the United States. * '''Philip Trammell Shutze: Atlanta Classicist, Connoisseur, and Collector''' exhibit tells the story of [[Philip Trammell Shutze]], one of Atlanta's foremost architects, who was also known for his art collections. A Phillip Trammell Shutze designed house, the [[Swan House (Atlanta, Georgia)|Swan House]], is also on the grounds of the Atlanta History Center.
The Kenan Research Center includes 3.5 million resources and a reproduction of historian [[Franklin Garrett]]'s office.
==Historic house museums== [[File:ATLSwanHouse.jpg|thumb|The Swan House at night]] * The [[Tullie Smith House]] is an [[Antebellum architecture|antebellum]] farmhouse built by the Robert Smith family and listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. It was originally a small farm in [[Dekalb County, Georgia|Dekalb County]] with 11 slaves, comprising {{convert|200|acre|km2}}. The house was moved to the Atlanta History Center grounds in 1969, and it currently comprises the farm house, kitchen, blacksmith shop, smokehouse, double [[corncrib]], log cabin, and barn, and several gardens. The barn contains several animals including angora goats and sheep<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Tullie+Smith+Farm/117.html|title= The Tullie Smith Farm Webpage}}</ref> * The Victorian and Lee playhouses are miniature houses. The Lee playhouse is located between the McElreath Hall and the Tullie Smith Farm. It was donated to the Atlanta History Center in 1998. The Victorian playhouse is located beside the Boxwood Garden. It was donated to the Atlanta History Center in 1980, and has gone through six owners. * The [[Swan House (Atlanta, Georgia)|Swan House]], designed by [[Philip Trammell Shutze]] in the 1920s, is named for its many swan designs. It is surrounded by the Boxwood Garden, based upon Italian gardens as created in 18th century England by [[Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington|Lord Burlington]] and [[William Kent]]. The front landscape, two cloverleaf fountains and a terraced lawn, is one of the most photographed places in [[United States|America]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Swan+House/116.html/|title=Swan House Garden and Landscape|access-date=2009-01-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223115709/http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Swan+House/116.html|archive-date=2008-12-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * The Wood Family Cabin is a log structure located within the Swan House woods. It is used to interpret North Georgia settler and Native American life in the 1820s and 1830s, in the context of the [[Georgia Land Lotteries|Georgia land lotteries]]. Some of its logs were originally used for the home of Elias and Jane Wood, early settlers in the Piedmont region of Georgia (where today's Buckhead district in Atlanta resides). The original home was situated approximately two miles from the site of the [[Muscogee|Creek Indian]] settlement of Standing Peachtree and one mile south of the [[Chattahoochee River]]. The cabin was donated to the Atlanta History Center by Dr. and Mrs. Carl Hartrampf Jr., descendants of the Wood family, in 2014. * The historic gardens are located next to the historic houses. The Cherry Sims garden contains Asian and native south-eastern plants. The Frank A. Smith Rhododendron Garden and the Swan House Boxwood Garden feature native plants. The Quarry Garden features pre-settlement plants only. The Tullie Smith Farm Garden features plants used in 1860s gardening, and includes two parts: a field, filled with profitable vegetables, and a smaller slave's garden.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Gardens/7.html/|title=Gardens|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223115606/http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Gardens/7.html|archivedate=2008-12-23|df=}}</ref> * The Atlanta History Center also owns the restored [[Margaret Mitchell House & Museum]], home of [[Margaret Mitchell]] from 1925-1932 while she was writing the novel ''[[Gone with the Wind (novel)|Gone With The Wind]]''. The house includes the Gone With The Wind movie museum, the reconstructed apartment #1 in which Mitchell lived, changing exhibitions, and The Literary Center. This is ticketed separately and is located near the Midtown [[Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority|MARTA]] station.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gwtw.org/ |title=Margaret Mitchell House Website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212070924/http://www.gwtw.org/ |archivedate=2008-02-12 |df= }}</ref>
==History==
The Atlanta History Center was founded in 1926 as the Atlanta Historical Society (AHS). Initially, the society operated as an institution for historical discussion and appreciation but, by the next year, began publishing the ''[[Atlanta Historical Bulletin]]''. The AHS was first led by Walter McElreath (1867–1951), an Atlanta lawyer, legislator, and author for whom the Center's McElreath Hall is named. The periodical was later named ''[[Atlanta History: A Journal of Georgia and the South]]''; it was published until 2006.
In 1986 the still relatively small group received the DuBose Collection of Civil War artifacts, donated by Mrs. Beverly M. DuBose Jr. In 1989, the Atlanta Historical Society built the current museum to house the DuBose collection.
In 1990, the Atlanta Historical Society was renamed the Atlanta History Center. The $15,000,000 museum opened in 1993 with five exhibitions, including its first signature Atlanta history exhibition, ''Metropolitan Frontiers''. An $11,000,000 expansion, finished in 1996, added two new permanent exhibitions, ''Shaping Traditions: Folk Arts in a Changing South'' and ''Turning Point: The American Civil War''. The Kenan Research Center library was later expanded and the gardens reorganized, with a fourth permanent exhibition added, ''Down the Fairway with Bobby Jones''. In 2006, the ''Centennial Olympic Museum'' was completed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Centennial+Olympic+Games+Museum/103.html/|title=History|access-date=2009-01-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322154951/http://www.atlantahistorycenter.com/cms/Centennial+Olympic+Games+Museum/103.html|archive-date=2009-03-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In 2014, the city of Atlanta announced its intentions to relocate the [[Atlanta Cyclorama & Civil War Museum|Atlanta Cyclorama and its artifacts]] to the Atlanta History Center, including the antebellum [[Western and Atlantic Railroad|Western & Atlantic]] locomotive, the ''[[The Texas (locomotive)|Texas]]''. The museum plans to construct an expansion to house the 360-degree [[panoramic painting]] of the [[American Civil War|Civil War,]] [[Battle of Atlanta|the ''Battle of Atlanta'']], as well as the ''Texas'' locomotive, and other pieces in the Cyclorama collection. The expanded history center is planned to be completed in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsculture.blog.ajc.com/2014/07/23/cyclorama-to-move-from-grant-park-to-atlanta-history-center/|title=Atlanta Cyclorama moving: Historic Civil War painting and diorama - Atlanta Life and Culture Blog|first=Howard|last=Pousner|date=|work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|accessdate=19 April 2017 |deadurl=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421001515/http://artsculture.blog.ajc.com/2014/07/23/cyclorama-to-move-from-grant-park-to-atlanta-history-center/ |archive-date=April 21, 2015}}</ref>
==Accessibility==
Paved pathways through the historic gardens connect to the Swan House and the Tullie Smith Farm, but most paths are unpaved. Large-print books are available for a few exhibitions in the Atlanta History Museum and videos have subtitles. Maps are available in [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]].
==References== {{reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Prince Charles, Duke of Cornwall Allan Warren.jpg|thumb|[[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]], pictured, has authored many books in his lifetime]]
The bibliography of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], is a list of approximately three dozen works which the Prince has authored, co-authored, [[Illustrator|illustrated]] or narrated and includes works for which he has written a [[foreword]], [[Introduction (essay)|introduction]] or [[preface]].<!--NOTE: THE NAMING CONVENTION IN THIS BIBLIOGRAPHY CORRESPONDS WITH (1) THE AUTHOR CREDITS ON AND IN THE PUBLISHED WORKS, AND (2) THE WIKIPEDIA BIOGRAPHY ARTICLE.-->
Any [[royalties]] the Prince receives go to [[The Prince's Charities Foundation]],<ref name="CharitiesAccounts"/> as do any profits from [[Waitrose Duchy Organic|Duchy Originals]].
==Author== *''[[The Old Man of Lochnagar]]''. Illustrated by [[Hugh Casson|Sir Hugh Maxwell Casson]], [[Royal Victorian Order|K.C.V.O.]] London: [[Hamish Hamilton]], 1980. Hardcover: {{ISBN|0-241-10527-7}}. *''[[A Vision of Britain: A Personal View of Architecture|A Vision of Britain]]''. [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] (1989). {{ISBN|978-0-385-26903-2}}. *''Rain Forest Lecture''. [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Royal Botanic Gardens]] (1990). Paperback: {{ISBN|0-947643-25-7}}. *''HRH the Prince of Wales Watercolours''. [[Little, Brown and Company]], (1991). Hardcover: {{ISBN|0-8212-1881-6}}.
==Co-author== * ''Mary Rose''. With [[Armand Hammer]]. New York: The Sarpedon Press, eds. Photographs: Pat Baker, Christopher Dobbs, Dominic Fontana, Steve Foote. Illustrations: Tayburn London, Arthur Barbose, Nick Evans, Debby Fulford. [[Portsmouth, England|Portsmouth]]: The [[Mary Rose]] Trust (1985). {{ASIN|B000FBLSNW}}. *''Architecture & the Environment: HRH The Prince of Wales and the Earth in Balance (Architectural Design Profile)''. With Andreas C. Papadakis. [[John Wiley & Sons]] (1993). Paperback: {{ISBN|1-85490-143-5}}. *''Highgrove: An Experiment in Organic Gardening and Farming''. With Charles Clover, environment editor for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', photography by Andrew Lawson. New York City: [[Simon & Schuster]] (1993). Hardcover: {{ISBN|0-671-79177-X}}. * ''Portrait of an Estate''. With Charles Clover. Photography by Andrew Lawson. London: A. G. Carrick. (1993). {{ISBN|978-0-7538-0018-8}}. *''Princes As Patrons: The Art Collections of the Princes of Wales from the Renaissance to the Present Day: An Exhibition from the Royal Collection''. With Mark Evans, Oliver Millar, [[National Museum Cardiff|National Museum and Gallery, Cardiff]]. Merrell Holberton (1998). Hardcover: {{ISBN|1-85894-054-0}}. *''The Parks and Gardens of Cornwall''. With Douglas Ellory Pett. [[Cornwall]]: Alison Hodge Publishers (1998). Hardcover: {{ISBN|0-906720-27-3}}. *''Respect for the Earth: Sustainable Development.'' revision.comment: /* Etymology */ Changed phi to correct typographic character instead of the technical symbol
revision.text:
[[File:Final concord on land in Lincoln 31 Edw. I.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|An English property conveyance (a [[Fine of lands|final concord]]) in triplicate chirograph form, dating from 1303. The word ''cirographum'' can be seen written twice, vertically and horizontally, along both cuts. The two copies of the agreement at the top were intended for retention by the two parties to the transaction; while the third copy (the "[[Feet of fines|foot of fine]]") was for retention by the court that oversaw the process.]]
A '''chirograph''' is a medieval document, which has been written in [[wikt:duplicate|duplicate]], [[wikt:triplicate|triplicate]] or very occasionally quadruplicate (four copies) on a single piece of parchment, with the Latin word ''chirographum'' (occasionally replaced by some other term) written across the middle, and then cut through to separate the parts. The term also refers to a [[papal decree]] whose circulation is limited to the [[Roman curia]].
==Etymology== The Latin word ''chirographum'', often spelled ''cirographum'' or ''cyrographum'' in the medieval period, is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] χειρόγραφον, and simply means "handwritten".
==Description== The intention of the chirograph was to produce two (or more) identical written copies of a legal agreement, that could be retained by each party to the transaction, and if necessary verified at a later date through comparison with one another. The cut itself would generally be made with a wavy or serrated edge, running through the word ''chirographum'', to allow the copies to be matched physically as a safeguard against forgery. The earliest surviving portion of a chirograph in England dates from the middle of the ninth century.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lowe |first=Kathryn A. |chapter=Lay Literacy in Anglo-Saxon England: the Development of the Chirograph |title=Anglo Saxon Manuscripts and their Heritage |editor1-first=P. |editor1-last=Pulsiano |editor2-first=E. |editor2-last=Treharne |place=Aldershot |publisher=Ashgate |year=1997 |pages=161–204 }}</ref>
The practice of separating the copies with an irregular cut also gave rise to the description of the documents as "[[indenture]]s", since the edges would be said to be "indented".<ref>{{cite book |last=Brown |first=M. P. |authorlink=Michelle P. Brown |title=A Guide To Western Historical Scripts From Antiquity to 1600 |publisher=British Library |place=London |year=1990 |isbn=0712301771 |pages=78–9}}</ref> In the post-medieval period, as legal documents grew in length and complexity, it became impractical to fit two duplicate texts onto a single sheet of parchment. It therefore became more usual to make the two copies on two or more separate sheets, the top edges of which were still cut with a symbolic or matching wavy line.<ref>{{cite book |first=N. W. |last=Alcock |title=Old Title Deeds: a guide for local and family historians |publisher=Phillimore |place=Chichester |year=1986 |isbn=0-85033-593-0 |pages=35–6, 58 }}</ref>
==Ecclesiastical use== A more restricted use of the term is to describe a [[papal decree]] whose circulation—unlike an [[encyclical]]—is limited to the [[Roman curia]].<ref>Pollard, p. xvi.</ref>
Pope Francis on June 26, 2013 used a chirograph to set up a Commission to investigate the decisions and underlying investments of the [[Institute for the Works of Religion]] (the so-called "Vatican Bank"). The document was "an instrument under canon law giving the commission legal force, and expressing its broad aim to help ensure that 'the principles of the Gospel also permeate activities of an economic and financial nature.'"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ncronline.org/news/vatican/pope-creates-commission-study-activities-mission-vatican-bank |title=Pope creates commission to study activities, mission of Vatican bank |first1=Carol |last1=Glatz |first2=Cindy |last2=Wooden |newspaper=National Catholic Reporter |date=26 June 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2016 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Indenture]], a similar document recording an important agreement, formerly including slavery and apprenticeships, latterly in relation to certain major land dealings or certain debts of money, retained in a few and dwindling number of jurisdictions *[[Fine of lands]], or final concord, a type of property conveyance in chirograph form common in medieval and post-medieval England *[[Tally stick]], or split tally, a comparable system of creating matching copies of simple accounting records on a split stick
==References== *Bedos-Rezak, Brigitte (2010). "Cutting Edge: The Economy of Mediality in Twelfth-Century Chirographic Writing.” In ''Das Mittelalter'' 15: 134-161. *{{cite book |last=Lowe |first=Kathryn A. |chapter=Lay Literacy in Anglo-Saxon England: the Development of the Chirograph |title=Anglo Saxon Manuscripts and their Heritage |editor1-first=P. |editor1-last=Pulsiano |editor2-first=E. |editor2-last=Treharne |place=Aldershot |publisher=Ashgate |year=1997 |pages=161–204 }} *{{cite book |last=Pollard |first=John F. |authorlink=John F. Pollard |year=2005 |title=Money and the Rise of the Modern Papacy: Financing the Vatican, 1850–1950 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |place=Cambridge |isbn=0521812046 }}
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://medievalwriting.50megs.com/word/chirograph.htm Chirographs, Indentures and Final Concords] Medieval Writing. Retrieved on August 7, 2008. *[http://asv.vatican.va/en/dipl/chirograph.htm Vatican page on Chirographs]
[[Category:Documents of the Catholic Church]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use British English|date=March 2013}} {{infobox museum |name= Churchill War Rooms |image=MapRoomCabinetWarRoomsTrim.jpg |caption=The Map Room of the Cabinet War Rooms |established= {{Start date and age|1984|df=y}} |location= King Charles Street
[[London]], [[SW postcode area|SW1]]
United Kingdom |visitors=534,723 (2017){{cite web|title=ALVA - Association of Leading Visitor Attractions|url=http://www.alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=423|website=www.alva.org.uk|accessdate=20 April 2018}} |director= Phil Reed |publictransit={{rint|london|underground}} {{lus|Westminster}} |website= [http://www.iwm.org.uk/visits/churchill-war-rooms Churchill War Rooms] |network= IWM}} The '''Churchill War Rooms''' is a museum in [[London]] and one of the five branches of the [[Imperial War Museum]]. The museum comprises the ''Cabinet War Rooms'', a historic underground complex that housed a British government command centre throughout the [[Second World War]], and the ''Churchill Museum'', a biographical museum exploring the life of British statesman [[Winston Churchill]]. Construction of the Cabinet War Rooms, located beneath the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] building in the [[Whitehall]] area of [[City of Westminster|Westminster]], began in 1938. They became fully operational on 27 August 1939, a week before [[Timeline of World War II (1939)|Britain declared war on Germany]]. The War Rooms remained in operation throughout the Second World War, before being abandoned in August 1945 after the [[surrender of Japan]]. After the war, the historic value of the Cabinet War Rooms was recognised. Their preservation became the responsibility of the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]] and later the [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Department for the Environment]], during which time very limited numbers of the public were able to visit by appointment. In the early 1980s the Imperial War Museum was asked to take over the administration of the site, and the Cabinet War Rooms were opened to the public in April 1984. The museum was reopened in 2005 following a major redevelopment as the Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms, but in 2010 this title was shortened to the Churchill War Rooms. ==Construction== In 1936 the [[Air Ministry]], the British government department responsible for the [[Royal Air Force]], believed that in the event of war enemy aerial bombing of London would cause up to 200,000 casualties per week.{{Cite book|title=Churchill’s Bunker: The Secret Headquarters at the Heart of Britain’s Victory |last=Holmes |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Holmes (military historian) |year=2009 |publisher=Profile Books Ltd |location=London |isbn=978-1-84668-225-4 |page=15 |url= |accessdate=}} [[British government]] commissions under [[Warren Fisher]] and [[Sir James Rae]] in 1937 and 1938 considered that key government offices should be dispersed from central London to the suburbs,For example, the war room facility codenamed [[Paddock (war rooms)|Paddock]] in [[Dollis Hill]], north west London, was completed in June 1940. and non-essential offices to the [[English Midlands|Midlands]] or [[North West England|North West]].{{Sfn|Holmes|2009|pp=22–3}} Pending this dispersal, in May 1938 [[Hastings Ismay, 1st Baron Ismay|Sir Hastings Ismay]], then Deputy Secretary of the [[Committee of Imperial Defence]], ordered an [[Office of Works]] survey of Whitehall to identify a suitable site for a temporary emergency government centre. The Office concluded the most suitable site was the basement of the New Public Offices (NPO),{{Sfn|Holmes|2009|p=23}} a government building located on the corner of [[Horse Guards Road]] and Great George Street, near [[Parliament Square]]. The building now accommodates [[HM Treasury]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/about_1hgr.htm |title=The Treasury Building: 1 Horse Guards Road |author=[[HM Treasury]] |year=2010 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=25 August 2010}} [[File:Londres 189..jpg|thumb|The Great George Street face of the New Public Offices, the basement of which accommodates the Cabinet War Rooms.]] Work to convert the basement of the New Public Offices began, under the supervision of Ismay and Sir Leslie Hollis, in June 1938.{{Cite web|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100806153441/http://cwr.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.923 |archivedate=6 August 2010 |url=http://cwr.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.923 |title=History of the Cabinet War Rooms: Constructing the war Rooms |author=[[Imperial War Museum]] |year=2010 |work=Churchill War Rooms |publisher= |accessdate=17 April 2013}} The work included installing communications and broadcasting equipment, sound-proofing, ventilation and reinforcement.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|pp=28–9}} Meanwhile, by the summer of 1938 the [[War Office]], [[Admiralty]] and Air Ministry had developed the concept of a Central War Room that would facilitate discussion and decision-making between the Chiefs of Staff of the armed forces. As ultimate authority lay with the civilian government the Cabinet, or a smaller [[War Cabinet#Second World War|War Cabinet]], would require close access to senior military figures. This implied accommodation close to the armed forces' Central War Room.{{Sfn|Holmes|2009|p=18}} In May 1939 it was decided that the Cabinet would be housed within the Central War Room.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|p=23}} In August 1939, with war imminent and protected government facilities in the suburbs not yet ready, the War Rooms became operational on 27 August 1939,{{Cite book|title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |publisher=Imperial War Museum |location=London |isbn=1-904897-23-1 |page=2}} only days before the [[invasion of Poland]] on 1 September, and Britain's declaration of war on Germany on 3 September. ==Wartime use== During its operational life two of the Cabinet War Rooms were of particular importance. Once operational, the facility's Map Room was in constant use and manned around the clock by officers of the Royal Navy, British army and Royal Air Force. These officers were responsible for producing a daily intelligence summary for the King, Prime Minister and the military Chiefs of Staff.{{cite book |title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |page=13 |url= |accessdate=}} The other key room was the Cabinet Room. Until the opening of the [[Battle of France]], which began on 10 May 1940, Prime Minister [[Neville Chamberlain]]'s war cabinet met at the War Rooms only once, in October 1939.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|p=42}} Following [[Winston Churchill]]'s appointment as Prime Minister, Churchill visited the Cabinet Room in May 1940 and declared: 'This is the room from which I will direct the war'.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|p=55}} In total 115 Cabinet meetings were held at the Cabinet War Rooms,{{cite book |title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |page=5}} the last on 28 March 1945, when the German [[V-weapon]] bombing campaign came to an end.{{cite book |title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |page=19}} [[File:Cab War Rooms 3.jpg|thumb|The Cabinet War Rooms office-bedroom of [[Brendan Bracken]], Churchill's [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Minister of Information]].]]On 22 October 1940, during [[the Blitz]] bombing campaign against Britain, it was decided to increase the protection of the Cabinet War Rooms by the installation of a massive layer of concrete known as 'the Slab'.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|p=67}} Up to 5 feet (1.5 metres) thick, the Slab was progressively extended and by spring 1941 the increased protection had enabled the Cabinet War Rooms to expand to three times their original size.{{Sfn|Holmes|2009|p=80}} While the usage of many of the War Rooms' individual rooms changed over the course of the war, the facility included dormitories for staff, private bedrooms for military officers and senior ministers, and rooms for typists or [[telephone switchboard]] operators.{{cite book |title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |page=11}} Two other notable rooms include the Transatlantic Telephone Room and Churchill's office-bedroom. From 1943, a [[SIGSALY]] code-scrambling encrypted telephone was installed in the basement of [[Selfridges, Oxford Street]] connected to a similar terminal in the [[Pentagon building]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nsa.gov/about/cryptologic_heritage/center_crypt_history/publications/sigsaly_story.shtml|title=Sigsaly Story|author=Patrick D. Weadon|publisher=[[National Security Agency]]|accessdate=3 January 2012}} This enabled Churchill to speak securely with American [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|President Roosevelt]] in Washington, with the first conference taking place on 15 July 1943. Later extensions were installed to both 10 Downing Street and the specially constructed Transatlantic Telephone Room within the Cabinet War Rooms.{{cite book |title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |page=7url= |accessdate=}} Churchill's office-bedroom included [[BBC]] broadcasting equipment; Churchill made four wartime broadcasts from the Cabinet War Rooms. Although the office room was also fitted out as a bedroom, Churchill rarely slept underground,{{cite book |title=Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms (guidebook) |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |page=16}} preferring to sleep at [[10 Downing Street]] or the No.10 Annexe, a flat in the New Public Offices directly above the Cabinet War Rooms.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|pp=80–1}} His daughter [[Mary Soames]] often slept in the bedroom allocated to Mrs Churchill.{{sfn|Holmes|2009|p=83}}{{where?|date=November 2018}} ==Abandonment and preservation== After the end of the war, the Cabinet War Rooms became redundant and were abandoned. Their maintenance became the responsibility of the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]]. In March 1948 the question of public access to the War Rooms was raised in Parliament and the Minister responsible, [[Charles Key]] [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|MP]], considered that 'it would not be practicable to throw open for inspection by the general public accommodation which forms part of an office where confidential work is carried on'.[[Hansard]], 8 March 1948; 'War Cabinet Rooms HC Deb 8 March 1948 vol 448 c115W' [http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1948/mar/08/war-cabinet-rooms#S5CV0448P0_19480308_CWA_27 Hansard 1803-2005]. Accessed 20 January 2010. Even so, a tour was organised for journalists on 17 March, with members of the press being welcomed by [[Hastings Ismay, 1st Baron Ismay|Lord Ismay]] and shown around the Rooms by their custodian, Mr. George Rance.'War Cabinet Rooms: Scene Of Historic Counsels' (18 March 1948) ''The Times'' p.2 col.E While the Rooms were not open to the general public, they could be accessed by appointment, with access being restricted to small groups.Hansard 6 December 1978; 'War Room, Storey’s Gate HC Deb 6 December 1978 vol 959 cc681-2W' [http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1978/dec/06/war-room-storeys-gate#S5CV0959P0_19781206_CWA_140 Hansard 1803-2005]. Accessed 18 March 2009. Even so, by the 1970s (with responsibility for the Rooms having passed to the [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Department for the Environment]] in 1975) tens of thousands of requests to visit the Rooms were being received every year, of which only 5,000 were successful. Meanwhile, the atmospheric conditions of the site, being dry and dusty, were having a detrimental effect on the rooms' furnishings and historic maps and other documents. The prospect was raised of decanting the contents of the Rooms to an established museum, with the [[National Army Museum]] and [[Imperial War Museum]] being suggested as candidates. In the event, £7,000 was secured to conserve the material in situ. ==Opening and redevelopment== [[File:Churchillmuseumcabinetwarrooms.JPG|thumb|Public entrance, before the 2012 redesign, [[Robert Clive|Clive]] Steps with the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] building on the right and the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] on the left.]]In 1974 the Imperial War Museum was approached by the government and asked to consider taking over the administration of the site. A [[feasibility study]] was prepared but came to nothing, the museum feeling it did not have sufficient resources to commit to the War Rooms.During the 1970s the Imperial War Museum also became formally responsible for the former [[Royal Air Force]] aerodrome at [[Imperial War Museum Duxford|Duxford]] in Cambridgeshire (1976) and the decommissioned [[Royal Navy]] warship {{HMS|Belfast|C35|6}} in 1978. In 1981 [[Prime Minister]] [[Margaret Thatcher]], known as an admirer of [[Winston Churchill]], expressed the hope that the Rooms could be opened before the [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|next general election]]. The Imperial War Museum was again approached. Initially still reluctant, the museum's trustees decided in January 1982 that the museum would take over the site, on the understanding that the government would make the necessary resources available. The initial costs were to be met by the Department for the Environment and the War Rooms intended to be self-supporting thereafter.{{cite journal | author = Finch, Cressida | authorlink = | editor = | editor-link = | year = Summer 2009 | month = | title = A short history of the Cabinet War Rooms 1945-1984 | journal = Despatches: The magazine of the Friends of the Imperial War Museum | volume = | issue = | pages = 18–22 | location = London | publisher = Imperial War Museum | format = | arxiv = | id = | bibcode = | doi = | accessdate = 25 April 2012 | url = http://archive.iwm.org.uk/upload/pdf/pp18-21_CWR-spreads.pdf }} The Rooms were opened to the public by Mrs Thatcher on 4 April 1984 in a ceremony attended by Churchill family members and former Cabinet War Rooms staff. At first the Rooms were administered by the museum on behalf of Department for the Environment; in 1989 responsibility was transferred to the Imperial War Museum.Hansard, 23 March 1989; 'Cabinet War Rooms: HC Deb 23 March 1989 vol 149 c780W' [http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1989/mar/23/cabinet-war-rooms#S6CV0149P0_19890323_CWA_648 Hansard 1803-2005]. Accessed 18 March 2009 Following a major expansion in 2003, a suite of rooms used as accommodation by Churchill, his wife and close associates, was added to the museum. The restoration of these rooms, which after the war had been stripped of furnishings and used for storage, cost £7.5 million.Kennedy, Maev (9 April 2003) ''[[The Guardian]]'' [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/apr/09/arts.past Restored underground apartments opened to public]. Accessed 28 July 2009. In 2005 the War Rooms were rebranded as the Churchill Museum and Cabinet War Rooms, with 850 m2 of the site redeveloped as a [[biographical]] museum exploring Churchill's life, the development of which cost a further £6 million raised from private funds. The museum makes extensive use of audiovisual technology. The centrepiece is a 15-metre interactive table that enables visitors to access digitised material, particularly from the [[Churchill Archives Centre]], via an 'electronic filing cabinet'.Waterfield, Giles 'The Churchill Museum: Ministry of sound' ''Museum Practice'' No.30 (Summer 2005) pp.18-21For details of the development of the Churchill Museum, see {{Cite web | author=Pickford, John | title=Making the Churchill Museum | url=http://www.cassonmann.co.uk/publications/making-the-churchill-museum | work= | publisher=Casson Mann | date=March 2008 | accessdate=25 April 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220134228/http://www.cassonmann.co.uk/publications/making-the-churchill-museum | archivedate=20 February 2012 | df=dmy-all }} The Churchill Museum won the 2006 [[Council of Europe]] Museum Prize.Council of Europe (2009) Council of Europe Museum Prize (since 1977) [http://assembly.coe.int/Museum/PrixMuseeCE/PrizeWinners.asp assembly.coe.int]. Accessed 22 January 2010. During 2009-2011 the museum received over 300,000 visitors a year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=423|title=Visits made in 2011 to visitor attractions in membership with ALVA|publisher=Association of Leading Visitor Attractions|accessdate=25 April 2012}} In May 2010 the name of the museum was shortened to Churchill War Rooms.{{cite web |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100806154809/http://cwr.iwm.org.uk/upload/pdf/CWRMayHalf-termpressrelease2010.pdf |archivedate=6 August 2010|url=http://cwr.iwm.org.uk/upload/pdf/CWRMayHalf-termpressrelease2010.pdf |title=Churchill War Rooms – May Half-term 2010: Press Release |author=[[Imperial War Museum]] |date=11 May 2010 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=22 September 2010}} In June 2012 the museum's entrance was redesigned by Clash Architects with consulting engineers [[Price & Myers]].{{cite news |author= |title=Churchill War Rooms entrance |url=http://www.ajbuildingslibrary.co.uk/projects/display/id/5335 |newspaper=The Architect's Journal |location= |publisher= |date=2012 |accessdate=4 August 2014 }} Intended to act as a 'beacon' for the museum,{{cite web | url = http://www.culture24.org.uk/history%20%26%20heritage/war%20%26%20conflict/world%20war%20two/art387005 | title = New Churchill War Rooms entrance will reference military hardware, Jacob Epstein and Henry Moore | author = Culture 24 reporter | date = 25 May 2012 | work = culture24.org.uk | publisher = | accessdate = 19 June 2012 }} the new external design included a faceted bronze entranceway, and the interior showed the cleaned and restored [[Portland stone]] walls of the Treasury building and Clive Steps. The design was described as 'appropriately martial and bulldog-like' and as 'a fusion of architecture and sculpture'.{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/jun/01/week-architecture-dagenham-park-school | title = Constructive criticism: the week in architecture | author = Rose, Steve | date = 1 June 2012 | work = guardian.co.uk | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | accessdate = 19 June 2012 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/news/daily-news/clash-opens-new-churchill-war-rooms-entrance/8631414.article | title = Clash opens new Churchill War Rooms entrance | author = Waite, Richard | date = 8 June 2012 | work = [[Architects' Journal]] | accessdate = 19 June 2012 }} ==Notes== ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Sources== {{Cite book |last=Holmes |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Holmes (military historian) |title=Churchill’s Bunker: The Secret Headquarters at the Heart of Britain’s Victory |year=2009 |publisher=Profile Books Ltd |location=London |isbn=978-1-84668-225-4 |ref={{sfnRef|Holmes|2009}} }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Cabinet War Rooms}} *{{official website|http://www.iwm.org.uk/visits/churchill-war-rooms}} {{Coord|51|30|07.5|N|0|07|44.5|W|region:GB_scale:500|display=title}} {{Winston Churchill}} {{London museums}} {{Good article}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Museums in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:Biographical museums in London]] [[Category:Fortifications of London]] [[Category:Museums sponsored by the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport]] [[Category:Subterranean London]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials to Winston Churchill]] [[Category:World War II museums in London]] [[Category:World War II sites in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Imperial War Museum]] [[Category:Military communications of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Museums established in 1984]] [[Category:1984 establishments in England]]

revision.text:
{{See also|King's Advocate}} {{See also|Crown Counsel}}
'''Crown Advocate''' is a title used in Britain and some former British colonies for a government prosecutor. In former British Colonies and certain British [[extraterritorial]] courts the title is (or was) used by the senior government advocate. In modern-day Britain the title is used for entry level prosecution counsel employed by the [[Crown Prosecution Service]].
==Great Britain==
In the United Kingdom, the role of a Crown Advocate is to analyse, review, prepare and present a wide range of cases in the Crown Court and the Court of Appeal, including as a junior advocate in the more serious and complex cases. Crown Advocates will be expected to have an up-to-date knowledge of all criminal offences and will maintain a high volume of casework, which will include the review of more serious and complex cases.<ref>[http://www.cps.gov.uk/careers/legal_professional_careers/crown_advocate/ Job description of Crown Advocate from CPS website].</ref> There are also Senior and Principal Crown Advocates.
==British Supreme Court for China and Japan==
The position of Crown Advocate was created in the [[British Supreme Court for China and Japan]] in 1878. The first holder of the position was [[Nicholas John Hannen]]. The position was similar to the position of an Attorney General in a colony. The Crown Advocate was not a full-time employee of the [[Foreign Office]] but received payment for acting as Crown Advocate. The Crown Advocate was allowed to accept cases from private clients that did not conflict with his role as Crown Advocate.<ref>Clark, Douglas, Gunboat Justice: British and American Law Courts in China and Japan (1842-1943), Volume 1, p193-5 {{ISBN|9888273086}}</ref>
==Malta==
The position of Crown Advocate was created in 1839 to replace the office of [[Attorney General]]. The position was abolished in 1922 and taken over by the [[Treasury Counsel]]. In 1936, the role of Treasury Counsel was taken over by the newly re-created office of Attorney General.<ref>http://www.euro-justice.com/member_states/malta/country_report/2827/</ref>
==Australia==
===New South Wales===
The Crown Advocate is appointed under the provisions of the Crown Advocate Act, 1979 (Act No.59).
The Crown Advocate advises the Attorney General, particularly on questions arising under the criminal law, and appears for the NSW Government in criminal proceedings of special significance Under the Act the Crown Advocate assists the Solicitor General in respect of the exercise or discharge by the Solicitor General of any powers, authorities, duties or functions delegated by the Attorney General under section 4 of the Solicitor General Act, 1969.<ref>[http://investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/Entity.aspx?Path=%5CAgency%5C1937 NSW State Records Investigatgor]</ref>
===South Australia===
The Crown Advocate is responsible for the conduct of the State’s major civil and commercial litigation, and will act as senior trial counsel in more complex matters.<ref>[http://www.premier.sa.gov.au/images/news_releases/14_07July/crownadvocate.pdf South Australian Premiers press release 25 July 2014]</ref>
===Tasmania===
From 1973 to 1986 the senior government prosecutor in Tasmania was known as the Crown Advocate. The title was changed to [[Director of Public Prosecutions]] in 1986.<ref>[http://www.crownlaw.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0009/153864/ar2009-10.pdf Tasmanian Director of Public Prosecutions, Annual Report 2009-2010]</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Diana_MSG.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 240px | title = Diana (second version) | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]] | year = 1892-1893 | type = copper sheeting | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 14.5 | height_inch = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Philadelphia]] | museum = [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''''Diana''''' – also known as '''''Diana of the Tower''''' – is an [[Cultural icon|iconic]] statue by sculptor [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]]. Once a famous New York City landmark, the second version stood atop the tower of [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] from 1893 to 1925. Since 1932, it has been in the collection of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]].
The statue represents the goddess [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]].
==First version (1891-1892)== ''Diana'' was commissioned by architect [[Stanford White]] as a [[weather vane]] for the tower of Madison Square Garden, a theater-and-dining complex at [[26th Street (Manhattan)|26th Street]] and [[Madison Avenue]] in Manhattan. He talked his friend Saint-Gaudens into creating it at no charge, and picked up the cost of materials.<ref name="auto">"The Architect of Desire: Beauty and Danger in the Stanford White Family," Suzanna Lessard</ref> Model Julia "Dudie" Baird posed for the body of the statue.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Models/Dudie.htm</ref> Its face is that of Davida Johnson Clark, Saint-Gaudens's long-time model and mother of his illegitimate son Louis.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/17571 Davida Johnson Clark], from Metropolitan Museum of Art.</ref>
The first version – built by the [[W. H. Mullins Manufacturing Company]] in [[Salem, Ohio]] – was {{convert|18|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall and weighed {{convert|1800|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Monuments/Ideal/Diana1.htm</ref> Saint-Gaudens's design specified that the figure appear to delicately balance on its left toe atop a ball. However, the Ohio metal shop was unable to pass the rotating rod through the toe, so the design was altered and the figure instead was poised (less-gracefully) on its heel.
''Diana'' was unveiled atop Madison Square Garden's tower on September 29, 1891. The 304-foot (92.66 m) building had been completed a year earlier, and was the second-tallest in New York City. But the addition of the statue made it the city's tallest, by 13 feet (3.96 m).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JVzYO1TyZ6AC&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=madison+square+garden+tower+height&source=bl&ots=yk6wC1Fcyd&sig=mHLM8zLgVHCygH_8JP3I35PvQak&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBmoVChMIy-ydxsf5yAIVCmg-Ch26cwHp#v=onepage&q=madison%20square%20garden%20tower%20height&f=false Joseph J. Korum, ''The American Skyscraper, 1850–1940'' (2008)]</ref> The figure's billowing copper [[foulard]] (scarf) was intended to catch the wind, but the statue did not rotate smoothly because of its weight. ''Diana''{{'}}s nudity offended [[morality|moral crusader]] [[Anthony Comstock]] and his [[New York Society for the Suppression of Vice]].<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s9l5TIzarCUC&pg=PT61&dq=american+eve+the+statue&hl=en&ei=iYm5TtDtMaOQsALkvejZCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false| title=American Eve: Evelyn Nesbit, Stanford White, the Birth of the "It" Girl, and the Crime of the Century | author= Paula Uruburu| publisher= Penguin| year= 2009| isbn= 978-1-59448-369-1}}</ref> To placate Comstock and to increase the likelihood of its catching the wind, Saint-Gaudens draped the figure in cloth, but the cloth blew away.<ref>Federal Writers' Project. ''New York City Guide''. New York: Random House, 1939 {{ISBN|0-403-02921-X}} (Reprinted by Scholarly Press, 1976; often referred to as WPA Guide to New York City), pp.330–333</ref>
Soon after installation, both White and Saint-Gaudens concluded that the figure was too large for the building, and decided to create a smaller, lighter replacement. Following less than a year atop the tower, the statue was removed and shipped to Chicago to be exhibited at the 1893 [[World's Columbian Exposition]]. New Yorker W. T. Henderson wrote a [[tongue-in-cheek]] poetic tribute – "Diana Off the Tower" – a play on both the statue's name and situation.<ref>W. T. Henderson, [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/09/18/106890362.pdf "Diana Off the Tower" (PDF),] ''The New York Times'', September 18, 1892.</ref>
Saint-Gaudens served as head of the Chicago exposition's sculpture committee. His initial plan had been to place ''Diana'' atop the Women's Pavilion, but the city's [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]] protested and insisted that the controversial nude figure be clothed.<ref name="auto"/> Instead, it was placed atop the Agricultural Building.
The original ''Diana'' does not survive. In June 1894, eight months after the exposition's closing, a major fire tore through its buildings. The lower half of the statue was destroyed; the upper half survived the fire, but was later lost or discarded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jssgallery.org/other_artists/augustus_saint-gaudens/diana_of_the_tower.html|title=Augustus Saint-Gaudens' Diana of the Tower|first=|last=Natasha|publisher=}}</ref> <gallery> File:Davida Johnson Clark by Saint-Gaudens 1886.jpg|''Bust of Davida Johnson Clark'' (1886) by Saint-Gaudens. File:Diana 1st Version.jpg|First version of ''Diana'' in the foundry of the W. H. Mullins Manufacturing Company, Salem, Ohio, 1891. File:Agricultural Building (3572762953).jpg|Atop the Agriculture Building, World's Columbian Exposition, Chicago, 1893. </gallery>
==Second version (1893-present)== [[File:Madison Square Garden Diana.jpg|thumb|right|Second version of ''Diana'' with her copper foulard.]] ''Diana'' was completely redesigned by Saint-Gaudens – with a more elegant pose, a different thrust to the body, a thinner figure, smaller breasts and a more graceful angle to the leg. To better fit the proportions of Madison Square Garden's tower, the statue's height was scaled down to 14.5 feet (4.4 m).<ref>The Philadelphia Museum of Art's website lists the height of the figure as 13 ft 1 in (398.8 cm), and the height of the ball as 17 in (43 cm).[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/44513.html?mulR=241195760|1]</ref> The second version was made of hollowed copper, and weighed 700 lb (318 kg) – more than 60% less than the first version – light enough to rotate with the wind. As Saint-Gaudens originally envisioned, the figure was balanced on its left toe atop a ball. The statue was hoisted to the top of the tower on November 18, 1893.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1893/11/18/109733483.pdf| title=New Diana of the Tower| work=The New York Times| date=November 18, 1893}}</ref>
During the day, the gilded figure caught the sun and could be seen from all over the city and as far away as New Jersey. Electric lights, then a novelty, illuminated it at night; it was the first statue in history to be lit by electricity.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Monuments/Ideal/Diana2.htm</ref>
Madison Square Garden was slated to be demolished in 1925, to make way for construction of the [[New York Life Building]]. Prior to the building's demolition, ''Diana'' was removed and put in storage. The intention was for the statue to remain in New York City, however a seven year search to find a place to display it proved futile. In 1932, the [[New York Life Insurance Company]] presented ''Diana'' to the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] as a gift. It remains there today, displayed on the balcony of the museum's Great Stair Hall.<ref>[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/44513.html?mulR=967189961|8 Object record] in the Philadelphia Museum of Art's online collection.</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Philadelphia Museum greatstairhall.jpg| thumb|left|Saint-Gauden's second version of "Diana" on display in the Great Stair Hall of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. This is the same statue that sat atop Madison Square Garden from 1893 until the building was demolished in 1925.{{Deletable image-caption|date=May 2012}}]] -->
===Restoration=== [[File:Diana of the Tower Philadelphia Museum of Art cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Second version of ''Diana'' (restored, 2013-14), Philadelphia Museum of Art.]] When ''Diana'' was removed from Madison Square Garden in 1925, much of its gilded exterior was gone, having eroded away over three decades of exposure to the elements. The Philadelphia Museum of Art cleaned and repaired the statue in 1932, but the gold leaf was not replaced.
In 2013, scaffolding was constructed around the statue in the museum's Great Stair Hall for a year-long restoration. Conservators carefully cleaned its copper surface with chemicals and steam, removing nearly a century of dirt and grime. Samples of the small patches of remaining gold leaf on the statue were taken in an effort to match the carat, weight and color with its replacement. The statue's surface was then repaired and regilded with 180 square feet of gold leaf. Because it was known from contemporary sources that Saint-Gaudens did not like the look of bright gold at eye level, the conservators matted the gilding to reduce the glare and museum lighting designers adjusted the display lights for the interior display.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philamuseum.org/conservation/21.html|title=Philadelphia Museum of Art - Research : Conservation|first=Philadelphia Museum of|last=Art|publisher=}}</ref>
On July 14, 2014, the restored statue was unveiled and rededicated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2687882/Philadelphia-museums-golden-goddess-glows-again.html#ixzz3mOfi0n9r|title=Philadelphia museum's golden goddess glows again|publisher=}}</ref>
===Cultural references===
In the popular 1975 novel ''[[Ragtime (novel)|Ragtime]]'', author [[E.L. Doctorow]] suggests in a single line that showgirl [[Evelyn Nesbitt]] had posed for the second version of the ''Diana'' statue. Having grown up poor in the streets of a Pennsylvania coal town, Nesbitt had risen up to become “the Gaudens statue Stanny White had put at the top of the tower of Madison Square Garden, a glorious bronze nude Diana, her bow drawn, her face in the skies.”
The 1981 film version of [[Ragtime (film)|''Ragtime'']] expanded upon this incident as the cause of a major conflict between Stanford White and Nesbitt's millionaire husband [[Harry K. Thaw]]. In the film, Thaw demands that the statue be taken down from the top of the Garden as it is an embarrassment to him. The character is seen glaring angrily at the statue before shooting White to death at the Rooftop Theatre at [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] on June 25, 1906.
Both situations are completely fictional. The second version of ''Diana'' was placed atop the tower in 1893, when Nesbitt was only about nine years old, and eight years before she was introduced to White. {{clear}}
==Other versions==
===Half-sized statues=== [[File:Swanson4715.jpg|thumb|Half-sized ''Diana'' (1928), [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].]] [[Stanford White]] was so pleased with the 1893 second version that he asked Saint-Gaudens to create a half-sized copy in cement. This was installed in 1894 in the garden of White's Long Island estate, [[Box Hill Estate|Box Hill]], where it stood for many years. For the half-sized copy, Saint-Gaudens poised the figure on a half-ball. White's cement statue later was used to produce two bronze casts in 1928, and six bronze casts in 1987.<ref>John H. Dryfhout, ''The Works of Augustus Saint-Gaudens'' (UPNE, 2008), cat. 154, p. 207.</ref> The cement statue is now in the collection of the [[Amon Carter Museum of American Art]].<ref>[http://artmuseum.princeton.edu/collections/objects/33417 Diana], from Princeton University Art Museum.</ref> * [[Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site]], plaster. Saint-Gaudens's 1894 model. * Amon Carter Museum of American Art, cement. Stanford White's 1894 copy. * 1928 casts ** [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], gilded bronze ** Bass Hall, Fort Worth, Texas, bronze * 1987 casts ** [[Madison Square Garden]], New York City, bronze ** [[Brookgreen Gardens]], bronze<ref>http://www.brookgreen.org/AugustusSaint-Gaudens.cfm</ref> ** [[Princeton University Art Museum]], bronze<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!420595~!22&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Diana (Princeton University)], from SIRIS.</ref> ** Private collection, Saint-James, New York, bronze ** Private collection, Chicago, Illinois, bronze ** Private collection, Santa Fe, New Mexico, bronze
===Statuettes=== [[File:Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site SAGA2182.jpg|thumb|Statuette (foreground) and half-sized plaster model (background), [[Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site]].]] The [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] owns a bronze statuette of Saint-Gaudens's first version of ''Diana''.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!293600~!11&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 ''Diana'' (first version)], from SIRIS.</ref>
Capitalizing on the popularity of the second version, Saint-Gaudens modeled statuettes in two sizes: 31 inches (78 cm), with the figure poised on a half-ball, and 21 inches (53 cm), with the figure poised on a full ball. These were cast in bronze beginning in 1899, and vary in the configuration of bow, arrow, string, hair, patination, and base.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1985.353|title=Diana - Augustus Saint-Gaudens - 1985.353 - Work of Art - Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History - The Metropolitan Museum of Art|publisher=}}</ref> * [[National Gallery of Art]], bronze<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/collection/sculpture/noflash/zone1-3.htm|title=NGA Sculpture Galleries|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], bronze * [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], bronze<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/diana-saint-gaudens-augustus|title=Diana|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!26038~!124&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus ''Diana'', (sculpture)]. ''SIRIS''</ref> * [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], bronze<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!12453~!117&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus ''Diana'', (sculpture)]. ''SIRIS''</ref> * [[Williams College Museum of Art]], bronze * Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site, bronze * [[New York Historical Society]], bronze * [[Brooklyn Museum]], bronze<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/259/Diana_of_the_Tower Diana of the Tower], from Brooklyn Museum.</ref> * other museum and private collections.
===Busts and heads=== In 1908, the sculptor's widow authorized a posthumous casting of nine busts based on Saint-Gaudens's 31-inch (78 cm) statuette.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1446K2BT31887.1258&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!349897~!16&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Diana (bust)], from SIRIS.</ref> A 7-3/8 in (18.7 cm) plaster bust is at Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site. Bronze busts are at the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]],<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!12723~!5&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 ''Diana of the Tower'' (bust)], from SIRIS.</ref> and in private collections.
Bronze casts of ''Diana'' 's head are at Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site;<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!18560~!114&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus Diana, (head)], from SIRIS.</ref> [[Harvard University]];<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!10490~!1&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Head of Diana], from SIRIS.</ref> and elsewhere.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Diana (Saint-Gaudens)}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZ7dTBhL3oI&safety_mode=true&persist_safety_mode=1 PBS Documentary – ''Augustus Saint-Gaudens: Master of American Sculpture – The Diana'' ] *Jennifer Hardin, [http://hoodmuseum.dartmouth.edu/av/americanartatdartmouth/diana.html "Augustus Saint-Gaudens's ''Diana'' of 1891–93: Critical and Public Response to a Singular American Nude"], Hood Museum *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/34389/rec/62 ''Augustus Saint-Gaudens, Master Sculptor''], exhibition catalog fully online as PDF from The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which contains material on ''Diana''
